title: Fonterra supports tanker driver after fatal crash on SH1 in South Canterbury
text:
Fonterra supports tanker driver after fatal crash on SH1 in South Canterbury LIAM CAVANAGH AND BEN AULAKH Last updated 15:01, February 17 2017 BEN AULAKH/ FAIRFAX NZ 
A milk tanker lies on its side after a fatal crash with another vehicle near Glenavy. 
Fonterra is offering support for one of its tanker drivers involved in a fatal crash north of Oamaru on Friday. 
One person was killed in the crash between the milk tanker and another vehicle on State Highway 1 near Glenavy, 20 kilometres north of Oamaru. 
Police were still at the scene at 2.30pm investigating the crash which happened about 9.45am at Whitneys Creek. BEN AULAKH/FAIRFAX NZ 
A police officer directs traffic onto a diversion after a fatal crash in South Canterbury. 
Mid-South Canterbury Area Commander Inspector Dave Gaskin said diversions were likely to be in place for several hours. 
"The Serious Crash Unit is at the scene and an investigation into the cause of the collision is under way." 
Fonterra Co-operative Group Ltd global operations chief operating officer Robert Spurway said it received news of an accident involving one of its tankers on Friday morning. BEN AULAKH/FAIRFAX NZ 
Emergency service personnel are at a fatal crash on State Highway 1 in South Canterbury. 
"Our thoughts and sympathies are with those impacted by this tragic accident. 
"This is also a difficult time for our tanker operator, and we will be ensuring our people gather around him so that he has the right support and care." 
Fonterra had been working closely with emergency services throughout the course of the morning to help respond to the accident, Spurway said. BEN AULAKH/FAIRFAX NZ 
An ambulance heads away from the scene of a fatal crash on State Highway 1 in South Canterbury. 
A St John spokesman confirmed one person had died at the scene and another, who was initially reported as seriously injured, was assessed but required no further medical attention. 
Christchurch Transport Operations Centre adviser Luke Thomas said SH1 was closed south of Waimate, near Carrolls Rd. 
Traffic was being diverted down Old Ferry Rd and Glenavy-Tawai Rd, Thomas said. 
Fire communications shift manager Brent Dunn said Glenavy and Waimate fire crews were called out to the crash just before 10am. 
"We are currently dealing with a milk tanker versus car," he said. 
The crash was significant, he said. 
Drivers were asked to follow the requests of emergency services. 
Otago Helicopters chief pilot Graeme Gale said they responded straight away but were stood down on the way. - Stuff
